sen.j: 大喪の礼（たいそうのれい）とは、皇室典範第25条の規定により国の儀式として行われる天皇の葬儀の事。
sen.e: Taiso no rei means Emperor's funeral which is conducted as Imperial ceremony under the law of Imperial House Act, Clause 25.
Taiso no rei means an Emperor's funeral which is conducted as an Imperial ceremony under the law of the Imperial House Act, Clause 25.
Taiso no rei means an Emperor's funeral which is conducted as an Imperial ceremony under the law of the Imperial House Act, Clause 25.

sen.j: 皇室の儀式として行われる大行天皇の葬送儀礼である「天皇大喪儀」と区別され、国の儀式として行われる葬儀を「大喪の礼」という。
sen.e: It is separated from funeral ceremony of Taiko-Tenno (the departed emperor) as the ceremony of the Imperial Palace, 'Tenno Taisogi', the funeral held as nation's ceremony is called 'Taiso no rei'.
sen.cmt: 天皇大喪儀→読み方、定訳不明
sen.e: It is separated from the funeral ceremony of Taiko-Tenno (the departed emperor) as the ceremony of the Imperial Palace, 'Tenno Taisogi', the funeral held as a national ceremony is called 'Taiso no rei'.
A funeral held as a national ceremony is called 'Taiso no Rei' separately from 'Tenno Taiso Gi,' which is a funeral ceremony for the late Emperor held by the Imperial Court.

sen.j: 皇室行事は神道に則って行われる為、1947年の憲法改正以後初となる昭和天皇の大喪の際には政教分離の原則への配慮がなされた。
sen.e: The Imperial ceremony is held in accordance with Shinto religion, when there was Emperor Showa's Taiso no rei held in 1947, for the first time since the revision of the Constitute of Japan, after 'Sojoden no gi' out of 'Renso no gi' which is part of Imperial ceremony, 'Tenno Taisogi' was held, since there was a consideration of separation of government and religion, the objects with religious input such as torii (an archway to a Shinto shrine) was removed from the place where the funeral was, then national ceremony, 'Taiso no rei' was continuously held in the same place.

The Imperial ceremony is held in accordance with Shinto religion, and there was Emperor Showa's Taiso no rei held, for the first time since the revision of the Constitution of Japan in 1947, after 'Sojoden no gi' out of 'Renso no gi' which is part of Imperial ceremony, and 'Tenno Taisogi' was held, since there was a consideration of separation of government and religion, the objects with religious input such as torii (archway to a Shinto shrine) were removed from the place where the funeral was, and a national ceremony, 'Taiso no rei' was held in the same place.

Since Imperial ceremonies are held according to Shinto rules, the separation of religion and politics was taken into consideration when they performed the funeral ceremony for Emperor Showa, which was the first national funeral ceremony after the revision of the Constitution in 1947.

sen.j: 皇室の儀式「天皇大喪儀」の一部である「斂葬の儀」の内の「葬場殿の儀」の後、葬場から鳥居等の宗教的要素を持つものを撤去して、引き続いて、国の儀式である「大喪の礼」が行われた。
sen.e: They removed religious things such as torii (an archway to a Shinto shrine) after the 'Sojoden no Gi' within the 'Renso no Gi,' which is a part of the Imperial Court's private ceremony 'Tenno Taiso Gi,' in order to hold the national ceremony 'Taiso no Rei' after that.

sen.j: 昭和天皇の大喪の礼は1989年2月24日に新宿御苑において行われた。
sen.e: Emperor Showa's funeral ceremony was held at the Shinjuku Imperial Gardens on February 24, 1989.
Emperor Showa's funeral ceremony was held at the Shinjuku Imperial Gardens on February 24, 1989.
Emperor Showa's funeral ceremony was held at the Shinjuku Imperial Gardens on February 24, 1989.

sen.j: 葬列（車列）は自衛隊による21発の弔砲に送られて皇居正門を出発し、葬送曲「哀の極」の奏楽の中を桜田門、国会議事堂正門前、憲政記念館前、三宅坂、赤坂見附、青山一丁目、外苑前、青山三丁目を経て新宿御苑の葬場総門に到着した後、
sen.e: The funeral procession departed from the main gate of the Imperial Palace after Japan Self-Defense Forces made twenty one funeral salute, then while funeral music of 哀の極 was playing, it went through the Sakuradamon Gate, Kokkai gijido mae (in front of the Diet Building), Kensei Kinenka mae (in front of Constitution Memorial Centre), Miyakezaka, Akasakamitsuke, Aoyama 1-chome, Gaienmae, Aoyama 3-chome, finally reached the main gate of the place where funeral was going to be held in Shinjuku Goen.
sen.cmt: 哀の極→読み方不明 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The funeral procession departed from the main gate of the Imperial Palace after the Japan Self-Defense Forces made a twenty one gun funeral salute, then, while the funeral music of 哀の極 was playing, it went through the Sakuradamon Gate, Kokkai gijido mae (in front of the Diet Building), Kensei Kinenka mae (in front of Constitution Memorial Centre), Miyakezaka, Akasakamitsuke, Aoyama 1-chome, Gaienmae, Aoyama 3-chome, and finally reached the main gate of the place where the funeral was going to be held in Shinjuku Goen.

After the funeral motorcade departed from the main gate of the Imperial Palace as the Japan Self-Defense Forces made a twenty-one gun funeral salute, it passed the Sakurada-mon Gate, the main gate of the Diet Building, Parliamentary Museum, Miyakezaka, Akasakamitsuke, Aoyama 1-chome, Gaienmae, and Aoyama 3-chome with playing the funeral music called 'Kanashimi no Kiwami' (a funeral march composed by Franz Eckert) before reaching the main gate of the funeral place at the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden.

sen.j: 皇室の儀式（葬場殿の儀）として霊柩が轜車（じしゃ霊柩車）から葱華輦（そうかれん：天皇が用いる屋上に葱坊主形の吉祥飾りを着けた輿）に遷され、徒歩の葬列を組んで葬場殿に到着し、霊輦（霊柩がおさめられた葱華輦）が葬場殿に安置された。
sen.e: As part of Imperial funeral ceremony, the coffin was moved from hearse to Sokaren (a palanquin with decoration of good omen which had onion head shape being used by the Emperor), then the coffin was carried to the Sojoden and 霊輦 (Sokaren which had coffin inside) was kept in Sojoden.
sen.cmt: 霊輦→読み方、定訳不明 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As part of the Imperial funeral ceremony, the coffin was moved from the hearse to Sokaren (a palanquin with decorations of good omens which had an onion head shape that was used by the Emperor), then the coffin was carried to the Sojoden and 霊輦 (Sokaren which had the coffin inside) was kept in Sojoden.

Subsequently, in the Imperial Family's ceremony called Sojoden no Gi, the coffin was moved to the Sokaren (a palanquin for an emperor with a good omen decoration in a leek flower head shape on its rooftop) from the hearse before they formed a new funeral procession, and then the palanquin with the coffin inside was laid in state at the funeral hall after the procession arrived at the hall.

sen.j: その後、皇室の儀式としての奠饌幣や天皇の拝礼と「御誄」の奏上、皇后を始めとする皇族や親族の拝礼が行われた。
sen.e: After that 奠饌幣 which was Imperial ceremony, or Emperor's pray and the report of 'Oshinobigoto' (speech for the funeral oration), Imperial family member and other relatives pray were conducted.
sen.cmt: 奠饌幣→読み方、定訳不明
sen.e: After that 奠饌幣 which was an Imperial ceremony, or Emperor's prayer, and the report of 'Oshinobigoto' (speech for the funeral oration), Imperial family member and other relatives prayers were conducted.

After that, the Imperial Family performed some private ceremonies such as Tensenpei (a Shinto rite to present Shinto offerings such as cloth, paper, and rope), the present Emperor's prayer, a speech called 'Onrui' (a condolence message by the Emperor), and prayer by the Empress, other Imperial Family members, and their relatives.

sen.j: 以上の皇室の儀式の後に鳥居等を葬場から撤去して国の儀式である「大喪の礼御式」の開式を小渕恵三内閣官房長官が告げた。
sen.e: After the above Imperial ceremony, Torii and other things were removed from the place, the Chief Cabinet Secretary, Keizo Obuchi announced the opening of 'the ceremony of Taiso no rei' which was national ceremony, Akihito ahd Empress Michiko walked in front of Sojoden to pray silently for one minute, then Chiefs of three organization of powers such as the Prime Minister, Noboru TAKESHITA and others prayed and made funeral address.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the above Imperial ceremony, Torii and other things were removed and the Chief Cabinet Secretary, Keizo Obuchi announced the opening of 'the ceremony of Taiso no rei' which was a national ceremony, Akihito and Empress Michiko walked in front of Sojoden to pray silently for one minute, then the Chiefs of the three organizations of power, such as the Prime Minister, Noboru TAKESHITA and others prayed and made funeral address.

After these Imperial Family ceremonies were finished and religious objects such as torii were removed from the funeral hall, the Chief Cabinet Secretary Keizo OBUCHI declared the national funeral ceremony's opening.

sen.j: その後、明仁と皇后美智子が葬場殿前に進み正午から1分間の黙祷が行われ、竹下登内閣総理大臣を始めとした三権の長が拝礼の上で弔辞を述べた。
sen.e: Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko walked to the front of the funeral hall to offer a one-minute silent prayer at noon, and the heads of the three powers (legislative, executive and judicial) such as the Prime Minister Noboru TAKESHITA expressed their condolences after prayer.

sen.j: 陵所では再び皇室の儀式として「陵所の儀」が行われ、昭和天皇の霊柩が陵に納められた。
sen.e: In 陵所, 'the ceremony of 陵所' was held again as Imperial ceremony, Emperor Showa's coffin was put into the mausoleum.
